title: Surgical robots have been mooted for years, but they're still struggling to take off
text:
Keyhole surgery is tricky business. Surgeons who practice the minimally invasive procedure must learn to become adept with tools that are difficult to manoeuvre using an impossibly small incision in the abdomen of a patient.

It’s why the likes of CMR Surgical, a Cambridge-based robotics company worth $1bn (£812.7m), is creating robots that assist doctors in making keyhole surgery that much easier. Its Versius robot employs a number of robotic arms to help surgeons carry out the process.

But a future in which robots stand by the operating table in each and every NHS hospital up and down the country, which has been mooted for years, remains a distant vision as the surgical robotics industry confronts...
